title: Ekko's Comic...
body: was pretty good. I enjoyed it, and hope that Riot does more like this. It wasn't perfect, didn't answer all the questions I wanted it too, but hopefully they're going to answer those later. Keep this up and I'll stop complaining.

replies.body:
I can't tell if I like it or not. I want more (which should be a good thing), but I can't tell if that's because the comic was pretty anemic in any actual lore or because it was purposely designed well to leave me curious for more. The comic just repeats the same ideas that his small blurb and his animation already tell us. The blurb is suppose to be a summary so that's forgiven but I don't feel like I'm learning anything new except that Ekko blames himself for his friends death. 

I can't help but compare this to other game comics like Dota 2's or Dawngate's and feel like they executed theirs much better to Riot's. We get much more world building, character interactions and personalty revealed through theirs than we got from this. Now this can be because of stylistic choices and perhaps this comic is just the first in a series that expand on Ekko and Runeterra. Hopefully so, but I'm not sure this was the best intro to that then. Hopefully Riot will prove me wrong.

Yea, it was a good story no doubt, and the art was great, but I agree it leaves me wanting more. If Riot decides to make a series of comics (like the TF2 comics; those are awesome), I'd be ecstatic, but it seems like the lore we've been getting have been more like one-off experimentation/teasers on how they want to tell stories (Ekko's comic & teaser video, Bard's video and teasers, Amumu's song, Shurima event, Sion's rework reveal, etc.), instead of progression of a narrative

I agree. While I love variety, I think the way they are executing their storytelling feels very amateurish. It definitely feels like they don't have a plan or actual narrative plot because of the experimentation. Hopefully the "end" will justify the means. But as it stands I don't think its going to coalesce into anything more that a bunch of random snippets of vague lore and art.

Yea, the retcon seems like it was done more out of frustration ("we'd like to experiment more with the format/scope we tell stories") rather than having some organization/plan ("we're retconning the IoW in order to launch this/these new projects") for developing the lore of the game. I guess the few of us who weren't outright opposed to the retcon were hoping for like, serial content (comics, books, videos, etc) following champions/geographic locations. Kind of torn; the content they do put out I enjoy (aside from minor critiques), but there's a ton of untapped potential in the universe; so much just seems up in the air right now

EDIT: Not to rev the hype engines too much, but possibly there is more Ekko lore to come: From FauxShizzle, regarding the creation of the Z-Drive: ["I don't want to spoil this as ***we are working on this story***"](http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/miscellaneous/xEVZQjPL-champion-qa-ekko-the-boy-who-shattered-time?comment=00dd0000)

lol yep, this is why Ekko hates Piltover
I want to know how Ekko has such stamina that he can get faster after 88 sprints.

He takes shortcuts as much as he can, more and more each time.
He gets stamina back after rewinding, and if he is still tired, he can always spend some time resting before rewinding again.

In the animation we see him keep his injuries after each rewind.

I don't think he can rest long if at all. When he rests, he changes how far back in time he can go.

The pull chain seems to set the limit time of how far back he can go, basically when he starts the z drive. Dial on his glove sets how far back he wants to reset time since he pulled the chain. 

But you're right about him retaining injuries. The Z drive seems to only reset time for everything but Ekko.

Hmm. I'd have to find out more, if there is any more to find out. If he can set how far back he can go...then he's pretty much godlike. 

After 88 sprints, even with short cuts, he'd be exhausted. Unless he's superhuman.

This was certainly a point that annoyed me. Obviously not every run will have been of the same length, but Ekko has rewound time 93 times by the end of the comic and merely rewinds #78-93 alone could have taken something like 45 minutes to an hour if he's clocking in between 4:28 and 3:41. It's an inconsistency with how 'Seconds' showed us the Zero-Drive works that's kinda difficult to overlook.
Well he could probably rest between rewinds, meaning that rewind #87 could be a "rest rewind" with rewind #88 being the one he actually tries to save his friend on.
No, whe did see him keep THE PAIN of the injuries, not the actual injuries. (because then why did go back some of the times?)

https://youtu.be/FtEpp9lkfxA

At 1:34. He grabs his arm and is obviously in pain.
exactly what i said? he still has the pain, but his arm is not damaged.

Your question was unclear. 'Whe'? 

I know Gypsylord said he kept the pain but not the injury, but that just seems very odd to me. Without injury, where is the pain coming from?

From no place, is not real pain, is mental pain.

Do you know the term Phantom pain, where people feel pain of parts of the body that are not there anymore? is pretty much something similar.

i will put you in another way, the injury dissapeared, but your brain still thinks it hurts
But why? The injury never happened in this time. To me it seems inconsistent. Some aspects of a rewound timeline get kept, but not others.
Exactly, the injury never happened, BUT THE MEMORY OF IT STILL EXIST.

Memory doesn't necessitate carrying over pain or exhaustion though. I remember breaking my foot sure, but I don't feel pain from it when I do. I remember being exhausted from running a mile, but I don't feel exhausted when I do.

I'm not sure what to think of it yet. I'm glad it established a limit of sorts to the zero-drive, and I'm glad it actually had some form of conclusion. I'm still cautious, though; I'd rather not get my hopes up, only to be disappointed later.
Yeah that part confused me. He can't rewind that far? What happened to his device after it was shot? They have a pretty decent place to live. Why was that Pilte there?

From my understanding: He has to set a point in time to return to; he felt something was wrong, so he set a return point (probably around the time his friend got shot), and then ran out to find his friend. He kept running trying to get to his friend faster, but the point he set to return to was too late, and so he could never go back far enough to give him time to get to his friend before he got shot. This is why he decided to go get revenge instead

I think after it got shot, the device just broke, not sure. It seemed like he had to go back and fix it, but he said something about there not being enough parts (which may have also been a metaphor for him not being able to save his friend)

I'm guessing Piltover and Zaun are pretty geographically close; there seems to be a bit of crossover (Jinx, Vi, Ekko has a lot of quotes), maybe they're in the same 'city' more or less, just Piltover is the upscale neighborhood and Zaun is more like the slums/ghettos. The Pilte looked maybe like a cop or perhaps was there for...idk....illegal/black market stuff?

I guess they wouldn't change Piltover/Zaun's relative geographic location, though, at least not too much, since there are a few characters that have connections to both (ex. Jinx, Vi, now Ekko).

Game /= Lore.

He can only ult once because it would be broken and unhealthy if he could do so multiple times.

Game = Lore (Riot's new stuff isn't lore, because it's not story elements building on a video game anymore).

I figure the microcosm of the Field of Justice interacts differently with his [fancily-named-time-machine], and/or the Summoning ritual prevents him from utilizing the time bending properties fully, so he just pops backwards in his own time-state a bit, but doesn't actually reverse time (because that could end badly for the Summoner).

It makes sense to me at least, that the device is utilized differently because it's incompatible with the premise of fighting in the League.
